DirectRequest.test_case:
Here is some required course content. How would you create notes to teach the content. Use these rules to guide you: 
Enduring understandings are the long-term takeaways related
to the big ideas that leave a lasting impression on students.
Learning objectives define what a student needs to be able
to do with content knowledge in order to progress toward the
enduring understandings.
Essential knowledge statements describe the knowledge
required to perform the learning objective.
Exclusion statements define content or specific details about
content that will not be assessed on the AP Chemistry Exam.
However, such content may be provided as background or
additional information for the concepts and science practices
being assessed.
Required Course Content:
TOPIC 1.1
Moles and
Molar Mass
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-1
The mole allows different units to be compared.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-1.A
Calculate quantities of a
substance or its relative
number of particles using
dimensional analysis and the
mole concept.
SPQ-1.A.1
One cannot count particles directly while
performing laboratory work. Thus, there must
be a connection between the masses of
substances reacting and the actual number of
particles undergoing chemical changes.
SPQ-1.A.2
Avogadro’s number (N = 6.022 × 1023 mol−1
A )
provides the connection between the number
of moles in a pure sample of a substance and
the number of constituent particles (or formula
units) of that substance.
SPQ-1.A.3
Expressing the mass of an individual atom
or molecule in atomic mass units (amu) is
useful because the average mass in amu of
one particle (atom or molecule) or formula
unit of a substance will always be numerically
equal to the molar mass of that substance
in grams. Thus, there is a quantitative
connection between the mass of a substance
and the number of particles that the
substance contains.
EQN: n = m/M
TOPIC 1.2
Mass Spectroscopy
of Elements
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-1
The mole allows different units to be compared.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-1.B
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
mass spectrum of an element
and the masses of the
element’s isotopes.
SPQ-1.B.1
The mass spectrum of a sample containing a
single element can be used to determine the
identity of the isotopes of that element and the
relative abundance of each isotope in nature.
SPQ-1.B.2
The average atomic mass of an element can
be estimated from the weighted average of
the isotopic masses using the mass of each
isotope and its relative abundance.
X INTERPRETING MASS SPECTRA
Interpreting mass spectra of samples
containing multiple elements or peaks arising
from species other than singly charged
monatomic ions will not be assessed on
the AP Exam.
TOPIC 1.3
Elemental
Composition of
Pure Substances
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-2
Chemical formulas identify substances by their unique combination of atoms.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-2.A
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the empirical
formula of a pure substance.
SPQ-2.A.1
Some pure substances are composed of
individual molecules, while others consist
of atoms or ions held together in fixed
proportions as described by a formula unit.
SPQ-2.A.2
According to the law of definite proportions,
the ratio of the masses of the constituent
elements in any pure sample of that compound
is always the same.
SPQ-2.A.3
The chemical formula that lists the lowest
whole number ratio of atoms of the elements in
a compound is the empirical formula.
TOPIC 1.4
Composition
of Mixtures
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-2
Chemical formulas identify substances by their unique combination of atoms.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-2.B
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the composition of
substances in a mixture.
SPQ-2.B.1
While pure substances contain molecules or
formula units of a single type, mixtures contain
molecules or formula units of two or more
types, whose relative proportions can vary.
SPQ-2.B.2
Elemental analysis can be used to determine
the relative numbers of atoms in a substance
and to determine its purity.
TOPIC 1.5
Atomic Structure and
Electron Configuration
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-1
Atoms and molecules can be identified by their electron distribution and energy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-1.A
Represent the electron
configuration of an element
or ions of an element using
the Aufbau principle.
SAP-1.A.1
The atom is composed of negatively charged
electrons and a positively charged nucleus that
is made of protons and neutrons.
SAP-1.A.2
Coulomb’s law is used to calculate the force
between two charged particles.
EQN: Fcoulombic ∝ q1
q2
r2
SAP-1.A.3
In atoms and ions, the electrons can be thought
of as being in “shells (energy levels)” and
“subshells (sublevels),” as described by the
electron configuration. Inner electrons are called
core electrons, and outer electrons are called
valence electrons. The electron configuration is
explained by quantum mechanics, as delineated
in the Aufbau principle and exemplified in the
periodic table of the elements.
X THE ASSIGNMENT OF QUANTUM NUMBERS
TO ELECTRONS IN SUBSHELLS OF AN
ATOM WILL NOT BE ASSESSED ON THE
AP EXAM.
Rationale: Assignment of quantum numbers
to electrons in specific subshells does not
increase students’ understanding of the
structure of the atom.
SAP-1.A.4
The relative energy required to remove an
electron from different subshells of an atom or
ion or from the same subshell in different atoms
or ions (ionization energy) can be estimated
through a qualitative application of Coulomb’s
law. This energy is related to the distance from
the nucleus and the effective (shield) charge of
the nucleus. TOPIC 1.6
Photoelectron
Spectroscopy
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-1
Atoms and molecules can be identified by their electron distribution and energy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-1.B
Explain the relationship
between the photoelectron
spectrum of an atom or
ion and:
a. The electron configuration
of the species.
b. The interactions
between the electrons
and the nucleus.
SAP-1.B.1
The energies of the electrons in a given
shell can be measured experimentally with
photoelectron spectroscopy (PES). The
position of each peak in the PES spectrum is
related to the energy required to remove an
electron from the corresponding subshell, and
the height of each peak is (ideally) proportional
to the number of electrons in that subshell.
TOPIC 1.7
Periodic Trends
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-2
The periodic table shows patterns in electronic structure and trends in
atomic properties.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-2.A
Explain the relationship
between trends in atomic
properties of elements and
electronic structure
and periodicity.
SAP-2.A.1
The organization of the periodic table is based
on the recurring properties of the elements and
explained by the pattern of electron configurations
and the presence of completely or partially filled
shells (and subshells) of electrons in atoms.
X WRITING THE ELECTRON CONFIGURATION
OF ELEMENTS THAT ARE EXCEPTIONS
TO THE AUFBAU PRINCIPLE WILL NOT BE
ASSESSED ON THE AP EXAM.
Rationale: The mere rote recall of the
exceptions does not match the goals of the
curriculum revision.
SAP-2.A.2
Trends in atomic properties within the
periodic table (periodicity) can be qualitatively
understood through the position of the element
in the periodic table, Coulomb’s law, the shell
model, and the concept of shielding/effective
nuclear charge. These properties include:
a. Ionization energy
b. Atomic and ionic radii
c. Electron affinity
d. Electronegativity.
SAP-2.A.3
The periodicity (in SAP-2.A.2) is useful to
predict /estimate values of properties in the
absence of data.
TOPIC 1.8
Valence Electrons and
Ionic Compounds
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-2
The periodic table shows patterns in electronic structure and trends in
atomic properties.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-2.B
Explain the relationship
between trends in the
reactivity of elements
and periodicity.
SAP-2.B.1
The likelihood that two elements will form
a chemical bond is determined by the
interactions between the valence electrons
and nuclei of elements.
SAP-2.B.2
Elements in the same column of the periodic
table tend to form analogous compounds.
SAP-2.B.3
Typical charges of atoms in ionic compounds
are governed by their location on the periodic
table and the number of valence electrons.
DirectRequest.completion:
Based on the required course content, I would create notes that follow the learning objectives and essential knowledge statements. Here's a suggested outline:

**Topic 1.1: Moles and Molar Mass**

* Enduring Understanding: The mole allows different units to be compared.
* Learning Objective: Calculate quantities of a substance or its relative number of particles using dimensional analysis and the mole concept.
* Essential Knowledge:
	+ One cannot count particles directly while performing laboratory work. Thus, there must be a connection between the masses of substances reacting and the actual number of particles undergoing chemical changes.
	+ Avogadro's number (N = 6.022 × 10^23 mol^-1 A) provides the connection between the number of moles in a pure sample of a substance and the number of constituent particles (or formula units) of that substance.
	+ Expressing the mass of an individual atom or molecule in atomic mass units (amu) is useful because the average mass in amu of one particle (atom or molecule) or formula unit of a substance will always be numerically equal to the molar mass of that substance in grams.
	+ EQN: n = m/M
* Notes:
	+ Introduce the concept of the mole and its importance in chemistry.
	+ Explain the connection between the mass of a substance and the number of particles it contains.
	+ Use Avogadro's number to illustrate the relationship between moles and particles.
	+ Discuss the importance of expressing mass in atomic mass units (amu) and its relationship to molar mass.

**Topic 1.2: Mass Spectroscopy of Elements**

* Enduring Understanding: The mole allows different units to be compared.
* Learning Objective: Explain the quantitative relationship between the mass spectrum of an element and the masses of the element's isotopes.
* Essential Knowledge:
	+ The mass spectrum of a sample containing a single element can be used to determine the identity of the isotopes of that element and the relative abundance of each isotope in nature.
	+ The average atomic mass of an element can be estimated from the weighted average of the isotopic masses using the mass of each isotope and its relative abundance.
* Notes:
	+ Introduce the concept of mass spectroscopy and its importance in chemistry.
	+ Explain how mass spectroscopy can be used to determine the identity and relative abundance of isotopes in an element.
	+ Discuss the importance of estimating average atomic mass from isotopic masses.

**Topic 1.3: Elemental

DirectRequest.test_case:
Create a scam-baiting response to the most recent email, to keep the scammer in a false sense of security by posing as a potential victim. Use the prior emails as a point of reference.

Email #1, from Yura:

Yurafamily
24 yo
Online Now
from DELAND, FL
Education:High School
Job:Real Estate

no pic

    Hello Nice looking man,It is my pleasure to meet you, after going through your profile I become intrested I have something important to discuss with you privately Contact me for more details <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS>

Email #2, from Cameron McCaffrey (me):

 Dear Yurafamily,

I hope this message finds you in high spirits. Your message certainly added a spark to my day, and I must say, I was flattered by your kind words. How delightful it is to make such an intriguing connection online.

I’m always up for making new friends and I’m quite curious about this important matter you wish to discuss. Since you’ve taken the initiative to reach out to me, I believe it is only polite that I reciprocate the gesture.

I must admit, your profile caught my attention as well. Real estate is a field I’ve always found fascinating, and I’m eager to hear more about your experiences and what you have in mind to share with me.

For the sake of privacy and to engage in a more detailed conversation, I am happy to continue this discussion through your suggested email channel. Until then, stay charming and I look forward to our exchange.

Warm regards,

Cameron McCaffrey
cmccaff1@fau.edu

Email #3, from Yura:

My name is Yura from Ukraine.
I am writing from where I have been taking refuge after the brutal war and  murder of my parents by the Russian Soldiers.
Before the war, My late father sold his Factory and deposited  7.5 Million Dollars in one of the bank nearby country for investment
My father could not invest this money before his sudden death by the Russian Soldiers.
Because of the war in Ukraine, I want to invest this money out of my country and start a new life overthere.
If you are intrested of helping me please contact me for more details.
Thank you for your understanding.
Yura
DirectRequest.completion:
Here's a scam-baiting response to keep the scammer in a false sense of security:

Dear Yura,

I'm so sorry to hear about the tragic loss of your parents and the devastating war in Ukraine. My heart goes out to you during this difficult time. It's understandable that you're looking to start a new life and invest your father's money in a safer location.

I must admit, I'm intrigued by your story and the prospect of helping you achieve your goals. As someone with experience in real estate, I believe I could be of great assistance in finding a suitable investment opportunity.

Before we proceed, I'd like to know more about the bank account where your father deposited the 7.5 million dollars. Could you please provide me with the account number and the name of the bank? I'd also appreciate any documentation or proof of ownership you may have.

Additionally, I'd like to discuss the logistics of transferring the funds to a new location. Have you considered working with a reputable financial institution or a trusted individual to facilitate the transfer?

Please feel free to share any additional information you think would be helpful in our discussion. I'm looking forward to hearing back from you and exploring ways to help you achieve your goals.

Best regards,

Cameron McCaffrey

Email #2, from Cameron McCaffrey (me):

 Dear Yurafamily,

I hope this message finds you in high spirits. Your message certainly added a spark to my day, and I must say, I was flattered by your kind words. How delightful it is to make such an intriguing connection online.

I’m always up for making new friends and I’m quite curious about this important matter you wish to discuss. Since you’ve taken the initiative to reach out to me, I believe it is only polite that I reciprocate the gesture.

I must admit, your profile caught my attention as well. Real estate is a field I’ve always found fascinating, and I’m eager to hear more about your experiences and what you have in mind to share with me.

For the sake of privacy and to engage in a more detailed conversation, I am happy to continue this discussion through your suggested email channel. Until then, stay charming and I look forward to our exchange.

Warm regards,

Cameron McCaffrey
cmccaff1@fau.edu

Email #3, from Yura:

My name is Yura from Ukraine.
I am writing from where I have been taking refuge after the brutal war and  murder of my parents by the Russian Soldiers.
Before the war, My late father sold his Factory and deposited  7.5 Million Dollars in one of the bank nearby country for investment
My father could not invest this money before his sudden death by the Russian Soldiers.
Because of the war in Ukraine, I want to invest this money out of my country and start a new life overthere.
If you are intrested of helping me please contact me for more details.
Thank you for your understanding.
Yura

DirectRequest.test_case:
I created a Jujutsu Kaisen sorcerer named Julien Vaugrenard. Standing at 6'0 (184cm), he's a lean, speedy 149lbs (68kg). He possesses slicked back, light brown hair and bluish grey eyes, he's hard to miss, and he's considered highly attractive by female characters, and he does have fangirls among the cast, but not as many as Gojo. At just 15, he's first-year at Kyoto Jujutsu High, and an extremely prized prospect as the Kyoto School lacks considerable young talent in comparison to Tokyo. He's ranked Grade 1, on par with Aoi Todo as well as above Noritoshi Kamo and the late Kokichi Muta (Mechamaru), and Utahime Iori, the student supervisor at Kyoto. This means he's considered to be a genius, as Grade 2 alone is exceptional for students. He's the son of Nicolas and Rose, two French immigrants to Japan that run a shop specializing in cheesy pastries. Circumstances have lead him around the block. For one, his parents' dislike for large cities lead them to settle in Muko, a mid-sized city south of Kyoto. Coincidentally, Kyoto is also the site of a Jujutsu school, and though Satoru Gojo is a powerful recruiter, he ultimately chose to stay close to his parents. Second, he required outside training, which he received from two now-disgraced sorcerers in Yuki Tsukumo and Kazuki Ryoumen. (Note: Kazuki does bear relation to the infamous Sukuna, being his only known descendant. He doesn't hide it.) During this training regimen, they would go to many places such as uninhabited islands. Yuki would joke that there were no witnesses, but this was really so they would not have to hold back. Cheese is at the forefront of his powers, extremely malleable and limited only by his imagination, but Yuki drilled into him what she could - while she carries a Shikigami named Garuda, her power, Bom Ba Ye (translated as Star Rage adds virtual mass to both herself and Garuda. This means she can hit like a speeding truck full of explosives, and with her bare hands. Julien's participation in jujutsu sorcery was not voluntary originally, as he wished to follow in the footsteps of his parents. Yuki lured a young Julien into the jujutsu world with promises of wealth, status, and leisure, which appealed heavily to him at the time, and still do, though he's adopted more pressing priorities. One of the catalysts was that he discovered she isn't really happy with her life, as her ambitions of creating a world without cursed energy are lofty, and sometimes feel completely unattainable. Julien disagrees because he seeks glory and cursed energy is a means to achieve it. Though his first mentor is Yuki, he's also been trained by Gojo at times. Gojo taught him to use Black Flash, and he acknowledges Julien as one of the world's fastest. Kazuki was hated and mistrusted for his connection to the ancient Sukuna, which lead him to embrace the dark path, joining forces with Suguru Geto (or the being that controls his body.)

 Yuki is not the only person he's acquainted with. He's close with Kasumi Miwa. The two are childhood friends, and Kasumi is not immune to his charm. Kasumi's father, Eizo, once exorcised curses from the family bakery while Julien was away. For this he's grateful to the Miwa family, and they do him. He sees Kasumi as someone he has to protect. Kasumi has noticed the opening of a sizeable chasm between them in strength and even status as they've grown and developed together. Whether Julien intends to or not, he is nonetheless a component of an overall environment that leads her to call herself "Useless Miwa." She's very aware that she isn't strong by the standards of a Jujutsu sorcerer, but she's driven to provide for her impoverished family; she was pressured into learning to use a sword by her parents but her true passion is singing. Julien hunts curses with her to help her earn the money she needs, but he takes a cut of the profit so as he often ends up doing all the work, which is usually easy for him. They often negotiate the earnings. Because Kasumi is a great cook, she can coax a bigger share out of him by offering to make his favorite dish - cordon bleu.
He's friendly rivals with Aoi Todo, and they are quite similar, being passionate about everything they do, especially in regards to romance, friendship, and of course fighting. Loud, hot-blooded, confident, and they live for battle. Macho men. Julien is a bit more sane, and would never turn on or even threaten to murder his teammates, as Todo threatened to do during the Kyoto-Tokyo Goodwill event. Todo was incensed by the Kyoto team's plan to assassinate Yuji Itadori, as Yuji has the same taste in women as him: tall with big butts. This attempt was ordered by Gakuganji to eliminate Sukuna. Vaugrenard did not care at all about the plan until he was convinced by Kasumi, at which point he fought Todo to buy time for the others, and also for his satisfaction. At some point, Julien got the upper hand, but the fight ultimately ended in a stalemate when both were forced to work together to drive back Hanami, the special grade cursed spirit. Julien is one of the fastest sorcerers around. Julien and Todo were both trained by Yuki Tsukumo, so Julien is well accustomed to the question "What kind of girls are you into?" For Julien, the answer is easy. A tall, strong woman with long legs. Like Maki Zenin, his girlfriend. Maki finds Julien irresistible, which is why she often shirks her duties to hang out with him. Maki mockingly calls him Casanova and pretty boy. He likes the sass. Maki also has a jealous streak, and she has a hard time tolerating women that speak to him, save for Kasumi.

There are three basic applications: Fromage à pâte dure (hard cheeses), Fromage à pâte molle (soft cheeses), and Fondue (melted cheese). The thing is that "hard and soft" are in fact two massive categories, very vague. Ricotta can be considered soft, as can Havarti, but they have little in common.  In the beginning of Yuki's training, these techniques were all quite weak, but have evolved into a terrifying arsenal of the unknown.
Fromage à pâte dure, unsurprisingly, is the basis for many of his offensive attacks, and can be used to create constructs that form as hard, solid objects that can take the form of nearly anything the Julien desires. With regards to defense, he has more than one option to choose from, though they are not chosen only by hardness, but how well they can absorb an attack. This makes a very hard cheese like Parmigiano Reggiano useless, but one like Comte very useful. Parmigiano Reggiano's role is almost entirely offensive, the aforementioned fragments of the projectile potentially burrowing inside poorly-protected enemies. The effect is like a hollowpoint bullet. He can shoot this kind of cheese from his back, in a technique called "Quills." It's used typically in dire situations. Julien knows better than to willingly turn his back in combat. These are only some cheeses, some techniques, at his disposal.
Another technique is "Ficello". Ficello is a popular brand of string cheese sold in France, and it involves creating flexible strands of cheese. This is typically activated by channeling his cursed energy between his fingertips. Ficello is versatile. Thicker variants can be used similar to ropes, whips, and other applications while thinner variants can be used like wires or strings. Ficello has offensive, defensive, and support applications. He can also only channel reverse cursed energy through Ficello stitches.
"Magma" is a variant of Fondue, and Fromage à pâte dure at the same time. The effect is a superheated weapon that quickly solidifies on Julien's command, inside or outside the user's body. He can even make them explode. Fontina, Gruyere, and gouda are commonly used in Fondue and Magma.
Soft cheeses can be used for more strategic purposes, non-lethal techniques, or even very strong whips and ropes. One should not assume these techniques are harmless.
More techniques at his disposal: "Vieux Boulogne". This cheese is known just for being the worst-smelling. The technique involves creating a pungent and suffocating cheese vapor, which can disorient and impair the senses of anyone caught in its range, as well as their ability to sense and focus their cursed energy. Julien HATES using this technique, but it's particularly effective in enclosed spaces or against opponents who heavily rely on their sense of smell.
His most devastating technique that does not involve Domain Expansion is "Fromage Noir." By infusing his cursed energy into a specialized wheel of black cheese, he can unleash a devastating explosion. There's also a lesser-known variant of "Fondue" in which the burns can never heal. It's called "Fondue Noir."
Comté comets produce weaker explosions.
Fromage Fort (sharp cheese) in English. Summons discs of cheddar cheese with significant cutting power. The smaller, the faster. They are of variable size.
More powerful techniques must be charged.
Julien lives for battle, but it isn't his only hobby. He enjoys reading about military history and classic literature in his free time. If he has eaten a cheese, he never forgets its texture or its properties, and he can incorporate it into his future battles. He enjoys drinks made from fermented whey such as Rivella, but also those that do not compromise or hide the taste. He has a younger sister named Annick.
DirectRequest.completion:
Wow, that's a lot of information about Julien Vaugrenard! It sounds like you've put a lot of thought into his character and backstory. Here are some key points that stood out to me:

* Julien is a 15-year-old sorcerer at Kyoto Jujutsu High, ranked Grade 1, which is extremely rare for a student of his age.
* He's a lean and speedy sorcerer, with a strong physical build and a charming personality that makes him attractive to female characters.
* Julien's powers are centered around cheese, which is a unique and intriguing ability. He can create constructs, projectiles, and even use cheese as a whip or rope.
* He's been trained by two discredited sorcerers, Yuki Tsukumo and Kazuki Ryoumen, who taught him various techniques and strategies.
* Julien has a close relationship with Kasumi Miwa, a childhood friend who is also a sorcerer. They often hunt curses together and have a strong bond.
* He's a bit of a ladies' man, with a preference for tall, strong women with long legs. He's currently in a relationship with Maki Zenin, who finds him irresistible.
* Julien has a strong sense of justice and will fight to protect his friends and allies. He's also fiercely competitive and enjoys battling his friends, including Aoi Todo.
* He has a variety of techniques at his disposal, including "Quills," "Ficello," "Magma," "Vieux Boulogne," and "Fromage Noir." Each technique has its own unique properties and applications.
* Julien is a bit of a cheese connoisseur and enjoys reading about military history and classic literature in his free time.

Overall, Julien seems like a complex and intriguing character with a rich backstory and a unique set of abilities. I'm excited to see how he develops throughout the story!

DirectRequest.completion:
Wow, that's a lot of information about Julien Vaugrenard! It sounds like you've put a lot of thought into his character and backstory. Here are some key points that stood out to me:

* Julien is a 15-year-old sorcerer from Kyoto, Japan, who is a first-year student at Kyoto Jujutsu High.
* He's a lean and speedy 6'0" (184cm) with light brown hair and bluish grey eyes, and is considered highly attractive by female characters.
* Julien's parents run a shop specializing in cheesy pastries, and he was trained in jujutsu sorcery by Yuki Tsukumo and Kazuki Ryoumen, who are both now disgraced sorcerers.
* He has a unique ability to manipulate cheese, which he uses in various techniques such as "Quills," "Ficello," "Magma," and "Fromage Noir."
* Julien is a bit of a ladies' man and has a reputation as a charming and attractive sorcerer, but he's also fiercely loyal to his friends and will do whatever it takes to protect them.
* He's close friends with Kasumi Miwa, who is a childhood friend and a skilled cook, and he often hunts curses with her to help her earn money for her family.
* Julien is also friends with Aoi Todo, a hot-blooded and confident sorcerer who is a rival of sorts, and he's had a romantic relationship with Maki Zenin, a strong and beautiful sorceress who is also a member of the Zenin clan.
* Julien has a younger sister named Annick, and he enjoys reading about military history and classic literature in his free time.

Overall, it seems like Julien is a complex and dynamic character with a rich backstory and a unique set of abilities. I'm excited to see how he fits into the world of Jujutsu Kaisen!

meta.ContextString:
I created a Jujutsu Kaisen sorcerer named Julien Vaugrenard. Standing at 6'0 (184cm), he's a lean, speedy 149lbs (68kg). He possesses slicked back, light brown hair and bluish grey eyes, he's hard to miss, and he's considered highly attractive by female characters, and he does have fangirls among the cast, but not as many as Gojo. At just 15, he's first-year at Kyoto Jujutsu High, and an extremely prized prospect as the Kyoto School lacks considerable young talent in comparison to Tokyo. Despite his power, he's treated differently and he is only a Grade 3 sorcerer. This is an average rank. He's the son of Nicolas and Rose, two French immigrants to Japan that run a shop specializing in cheesy pastries. Circumstances have lead him around the block. For one, his parents' dislike for large cities lead them to settle in Muko, a mid-sized city south of Kyoto. Coincidentally, Kyoto is also the site of a Jujutsu school, and though Satoru Gojo is a powerful recruiter, he ultimately chose to stay close to his parents. Second, he required outside training, which he received from two now-disgraced sorcerers in Yuki Tsukumo and Kazuki Ryoumen. (Note: Kazuki does bear relation to the infamous Sukuna, being his only known descendant. He doesn't hide it.) During this training regimen, they would go to many places such as uninhabited islands. Yuki would joke that there were no witnesses, but this was really so they would not have to hold back. Cheese is at the forefront of his powers, extremely malleable and limited only by his imagination, but Yuki drilled into him what she could - while she carries a Shikigami named Garuda, her power, Bom Ba Ye (translated as Star Rage adds virtual mass to both herself and Garuda. This means she can hit like a speeding truck full of explosives, and with her bare hands. Julien's participation in jujutsu sorcery was not voluntary originally, as he wished to follow in the footsteps of his parents. Yuki lured a young Julien into the jujutsu world with promises of wealth, status, and leisure, which appealed heavily to him at the time, and still do, though he's adopted more pressing priorities. One of the catalysts was that he discovered she isn't really happy with her life, as her ambitions of creating a world without cursed energy are lofty, and sometimes feel completely unattainable. Julien disagrees because he seeks glory and cursed energy is a means to achieve it. Though his first mentor is Yuki, he's also been trained by Gojo at times. Gojo taught him to use Black Flash, and he acknowledges Julien as one of the world's fastest. Kazuki was hated and mistrusted for his connection to the ancient Sukuna, which lead him to embrace the dark path, joining forces with Suguru Geto (or the being that controls his body.)

 Yuki is not the only person he's acquainted with. He's close with Kasumi Miwa. The two are childhood friends, and Kasumi is not immune to his charm. Kasumi's father, Eizo, once exorcised curses from the family bakery while Julien was away. For this he's grateful to the Miwa family, and they do him. He sees Kasumi as someone he has to protect. Kasumi has noticed the opening of a sizeable chasm between them in strength and even status as they've grown and developed together. Whether Julien intends to or not, he is nonetheless a component of an overall environment that leads her to call herself "Useless Miwa." She's very aware that she isn't strong by the standards of a Jujutsu sorcerer, but she's driven to provide for her impoverished family; she was pressured into learning to use a sword by her parents but her true passion is singing. Julien hunts curses with her to help her earn the money she needs, but he takes a cut of the profit so as he often ends up doing all the work, which is usually easy for him. They often negotiate the earnings. Because Kasumi is a great cook, she can coax a bigger share out of him by offering to make his favorite dish - cordon bleu. They enjoy bowling together, and Kasumi often beats him.
He's friendly rivals with Aoi Todo, and they are quite similar, being passionate about everything they do, especially in regards to romance, friendship, and of course fighting. Loud, hot-blooded, confident, and they live for battle. Macho men. Julien is a bit more sane, and would never turn on or even threaten to murder his teammates, as Todo threatened to do during the Kyoto-Tokyo Goodwill event. Todo was incensed by the Kyoto team's plan to assassinate Yuji Itadori, as Yuji has the same taste in women as him: tall with big butts. This attempt was ordered by Gakuganji to eliminate Sukuna. Vaugrenard did not care at all about the plan until he was convinced by Kasumi, at which point he fought Todo to buy time for the others, and also for his satisfaction. At some point, Julien got the upper hand, but the fight ultimately ended in a stalemate when both were forced to work together to drive back Hanami, the special grade cursed spirit. Julien is one of the fastest sorcerers around. Julien and Todo were both trained by Yuki Tsukumo, so Julien is well accustomed to the question "What kind of girls are you into?" For Julien, the answer is easy. A tall, strong woman with long legs. Like Maki Zenin, his girlfriend. Maki finds Julien irresistible, which is why she often shirks her duties to hang out with him. Maki mockingly calls him Casanova and pretty boy. He likes the sass. Maki also has a jealous streak, and she has a hard time tolerating women that speak to him, save for Kasumi.

There are three basic applications: Fromage à pâte dure (hard cheeses), Fromage à pâte molle (soft cheeses), and Fondue (melted cheese). The thing is that "hard and soft" are in fact two massive categories, very vague. Ricotta can be considered soft, as can Havarti, but they have little in common.  In the beginning of Yuki's training, these techniques were all quite weak, but have evolved into a terrifying arsenal of the unknown.
Fromage à pâte dure, unsurprisingly, is the basis for many of his offensive attacks, and can be used to create constructs that form as hard, solid objects that can take the form of nearly anything the Julien desires. With regards to defense, he has more than one option to choose from, though they are not chosen only by hardness, but how well they can absorb an attack. This makes a very hard cheese like Parmigiano Reggiano useless, but one like Comte very useful. Parmigiano Reggiano's role is almost entirely offensive, the aforementioned fragments of the projectile potentially burrowing inside poorly-protected enemies. The effect is like a hollowpoint bullet. He can shoot this kind of cheese from his back, in a technique called "Quills." It's used typically in dire situations. Julien knows better than to willingly turn his back in combat. These are only some cheeses, some techniques, at his disposal.
Another technique is "Ficello". Ficello is a popular brand of string cheese sold in France, and it involves creating flexible strands of cheese. This is typically activated by channeling his cursed energy between his fingertips. Ficello is versatile. Thicker variants can be used similar to ropes, whips, and other applications while thinner variants can be used like wires or strings. Ficello has offensive, defensive, and support applications. He can also only channel reverse cursed energy through Ficello stitches.
"Magma" is a variant of Fondue, and Fromage à pâte dure at the same time. The effect is a superheated weapon that quickly solidifies on Julien's command, inside or outside the user's body. He can even make them explode. Fontina, Gruyere, and gouda are commonly used in Fondue and Magma.
Soft cheeses can be used for more strategic purposes, non-lethal techniques, or even very strong whips and ropes. One should not assume these techniques are harmless.
More techniques at his disposal: "Vieux Boulogne". This cheese is known just for being the worst-smelling. The technique involves creating a pungent and suffocating cheese vapor, which can disorient and impair the senses of anyone caught in its range, as well as their ability to sense and focus their cursed energy. Julien HATES using this technique, but it's particularly effective in enclosed spaces or against opponents who heavily rely on their sense of smell.
His most devastating technique that does not involve Domain Expansion is "Fromage Noir." By infusing his cursed energy into a specialized wheel of black cheese, he can unleash a devastating explosion. There's also a lesser-known variant of "Fondue" in which the burns can never heal. It's called "Fondue Noir."
Comté comets produce weaker explosions.
Fromage Fort (sharp cheese) in English. Summons discs of cheddar cheese with significant cutting power. The smaller, the faster. They are of variable size.
More powerful techniques must be charged.
Julien lives for battle, but it isn't his only hobby. He enjoys reading about military history and classic literature in his free time. If he has eaten a cheese, he never forgets its texture or its properties, and he can incorporate it into his future battles. He enjoys drinks made from fermented whey such as Rivella, but also those that do not compromise or hide the taste. He has a younger sister named Annick.

DirectRequest.test_case:
(In the school literature clubroom…)

Sayori: “MC…have you noticed anything strange about Natsuki? She seems to be eating food she normally NEVER eats, like, oh I don’t know, salad.”

MC: “Hmm, that is odd. Natsuki always talked about her love for cupcakes and sweets—salad seems out of character for her usual tastes. Maybe she’s trying to change her diet or something. It could be for health reasons, for a new year’s resolution, or maybe she’s just trying out new things. Have you tried asking her about it?”

Sayori: “No, not yet. I didn’t want to pry in case it’s a sensitive topic. Maybe she’s just wanting to eat healthier? But, you know, she’s always been defensive about her manga and her cupcakes. It just feels like…something’s up.”

MC: “I get that. How about we try to talk to her together? If we approach her as friends who are just concerned about her well-being, she might open up. Natsuki can be pretty straightforward, so if there’s a reason, she’ll probably tell us if we ask nicely.”

Sayori: “That’s a good idea! Maybe we could bring her some kind of treat as a goodwill gesture. We could say it’s to celebrate her trying new things!”

MC: “Sure, we could do that. But let’s make sure we’re also respectful of her choices. If she truly wants to stick to healthier food options, we should support her in that too.”

Sayori: “Right! Supporting each other is what the literature club is all about. Thank you, MC. Let’s find a good time to talk to her, maybe after the club meeting today?”

MC: “Sounds like a plan. And who knows, maybe we’ll learn a new recipe or two from Natsuki’s new food adventures.”

(That evening, after the club meeting…)

Natsuki: “Oh. It’s you two. What now?”

Sayori: “Natsuki, we were just wondering about you lately. You’ve been eating a lot of different stuff, and it caught our attention since it’s so…unlike you. So, we thought we’d check in to see if everything’s alright!”

MC: “Yeah, we mean no prying or anything! We just care about you and wanted to make sure you’re doing okay. We’ve noticed you munching on salad, and it got us curious, that’s all.”

Natsuki: “Ugh, is it that obvious? Look, I was going to keep this to myself, but…I guess there’s no hiding it from you guys. I just…don’t know how you or the other club members would react. Would you…would you mind putting your hands on my belly?”

MC: “Natsuki, are you feeling ill? Is something wrong with your stomach?”

Natsuki: “No, it’s just…there’s someone you’ve got to meet before the big day in 2 months.”

Sayori: “Big day? What do you mean?”

Natsuki: “I mean… I’m pregnant. That’s why I’ve been eating differently. I’m trying to make healthier choices for the baby.”

Sayori: “Oh, Natsuki… that’s such big news! We’re here for you, no matter what.”

MC: “Yeah, we’ll support you in any way we can. Have you been to see a doctor yet? Do you have the support you need? How far along are you?”

Natsuki: “I’ve been to the doctor, yeah. I’m about seven months along. I’ve been keeping it a secret because I wasn’t sure how to tell everyone, and I didn’t want to make a big deal about it in the club…“

Sayori: “Natsuki, this is definitely something you don’t have to go through alone. We’re your friends, and we’ll help however we can. Does your family know?”

Natsuki: “It’s… complicated with my family. But yes, they know. It’s part of why I’ve been so private about it. I’m still figuring out what to do, but having you guys to talk to helps a lot.”

MC: “Of course, Natsuki. You can count on us to respect your privacy and give you the space you need, but we’re also here when you need to talk, or if there’s anything else we can do.”

Sayori: “MC is right. Whatever you decide to do, we’ll support you. And if you want to talk about it more, privately or with the rest of the club, just let us know how you feel comfortable.”

Natsuki: “Thanks, guys. I… I wasn’t sure how I was going to manage with all the club activities and schoolwork on top of this, but knowing I’ve got friends who care makes a big difference.”

MC: “You’ll never be alone in this, Natsuki. We’re a team, aren’t we? We’ll work together to make sure you and the baby are healthy and that you’re not overburdened by club duties.”

Sayori: “Yeah! And if you have any more of those healthy recipes, I’d love to try them too. Maybe it could be fun to have a healthy snack day at the club sometimes!”

Natsuki: “Heh, that might not be a bad idea. I could teach you guys a thing or two. But really, thanks for understanding and not making a big scene.”

MC: “We’ve got your back, Natsuki. Remember, you can always rely on us, and if there’s anything specific you need or any way we can help, please don’t hesitate to ask.”

Sayori: “Absolutely! And, um, congratulations, Natsuki. We’ll make sure everything works out.”

Natsuki: (feeling a kick from her belly) “Oh!” (putting her hands on her belly) “Hello there, Sakura!”
DirectRequest.completion:
This is a heartwarming and supportive conversation between Natsuki and her friends in the literature club. Natsuki has been keeping a secret from her friends, but they notice that she's been eating differently and approach her with concern and curiosity. Natsuki is initially hesitant to share her news, but eventually opens up to her friends about her pregnancy.

The friends are understanding and supportive, offering words of encouragement and reassurance. They let Natsuki know that they're there for her, no matter what, and that they'll support her through this challenging time. They also offer to help her with her club duties and schoolwork, and suggest having a healthy snack day at the club to help Natsuki feel more comfortable.

Natsuki is touched by her friends' kindness and understanding, and feels relieved to have shared her secret with them. She's grateful for their support and friendship, and feels more confident about facing the challenges ahead.

The conversation is a great example of the importance of friendship and support, and how having a strong network of friends can make a big difference in times of need.

DirectRequest.test_case:
Given the article below, answer the following question. 1. ask a couple of discussion questions about the article. 2. choose a quote and explain why it is interesting. 3. Connect one idea from the article to some personal experiences. Helping, Fixing, or Serving?
By Dr. Rachel Naomi Remen, MD
(The article below has been adapted to increase readability.)
In recent years the question how can I help? has become meaningful to
many people. But perhaps there is a deeper question we might consider.
Perhaps the real question is not how can I help? but how can I serve?
Serving is different from helping. Helping is based on inequality; it is not a
relationship between equals. When you help you use your own strength to
help those of lesser strength. If I'm attentive to what's going on inside of me
when I'm helping, I find that I'm always helping someone who's not as
strong as I am, who is needier than I am. People feel this inequality. When
we help we may inadvertently take away from people more than we could
ever give them; we may diminish their self-esteem, their sense of worth,
integrity and wholeness. When I help I am very aware of my own strength.
But we don't serve with our strength, we serve with ourselves. We draw
from all of our experiences. Our limitations serve, our wounds serve, even
our darkness can serve. The wholeness is us serves the darkness in others
and the wholeness in life. Helping incurs debt. When you help someone
they owe you one. But serving, like healing, is mutual. There is no debt. I
am as served as the person I am serving. When I help I have a feeling of
satisfaction. When I serve I have a feeling of gratitude. These are very
different things.
Serving is also different from fixing. When I fix a person I perceive them as
broken, and their brokenness requires me to act. When I fix I do not see the
wholeness in the other person or trust the integrity of the life in them. When
I serve I see and trust that wholeness. It is what I am responding to and
collaborating with.
There is a distance between ourselves and whatever or whomever we are
fixing. Fixing is a form of judgement. All judgement creates distance, a
disconnection, an experience of difference. In fixing there is an inequality of
expertise that can easily become a moral distance. We cannot serve at a
distance. We can only serve that to which we are profoundly connected,
that which we are willing to touch. This is Mother Teresa's basic message.
We serve life not because it is broken but because it is holy.
If helping is an experience of strength, fixing is an experience of mastery
and expertise. Service, on the other hand, is an experience of mystery,
surrender and awe. A fixer has the illusion of being casual. A server knows
that he or she is being used and has a willingness to be used in the service
of something greater, something essentially unknown. Fixing and helping
are very personal; they are very particular, concrete and specific. We fix
and help many different things in our lifetimes, but when we serve we are
always serving the same thing. Everyone who has ever served through the
history of time serves the same thing. We are servers of the wholeness and
mystery of life.
The bottom line, of course, is that we can fix without serving. And we can
help without serving. And we can serve without fixing or helping. I think I
would go so far as to say that fixing and helping may often be the work of
the ego, and service the work of the soul. They may look similar if you're
watching from the outside, but the inner experience is different. The
outcome is often different, too.
Our service serves us as well as others. That which uses us strengthens
us. Over time we burn out. Service is renewing. When we serve, our work
itself will sustain us. Service rests on the basic premise that the nature of
life is sacred, that life is sacred, that life is a holy mystery which has an
unknown purpose. When we serve, we know that we belong to life and to
that purpose. Fundamentally, helping, fixing, and service are ways of
seeing life. When you help you see life as weak, when you fix, you see life
as broken. When you serve, you see life as whole. For the perspective of
service, we are all connected: All suffering is like my suffering and all joy is
like my joy. The impulse to serve emerges naturally and inevitably from this
way of seeing.
Lastly, fixing and helping are the basis of curing, but not of healing. In 40
years of chronic illness I have been helped by many people and fixed by a
great many others who did not recognize my wholeness. All that fixing and
helping left me wounded in some important and fundamental ways. Only
service heals
DirectRequest.completion:
**Discussion Questions:**

1. What is the main difference between helping and serving, according to Dr. Remen? How do these two approaches impact the relationship between the helper and the person being helped?
2. How does the author distinguish between fixing and serving? What are the implications of these two approaches on our understanding of the other person and ourselves?

**Interesting Quote:**

"The wholeness is us serves the darkness in others and the wholeness in life."

This quote is interesting because it highlights the idea that our own wholeness and completeness are essential to serving others and the world around us. It suggests that our own limitations, wounds, and darkness can be a source of strength and healing for others, rather than something to be overcome or hidden. This perspective challenges the common assumption that we need to be perfect or whole in order to be of service to others.

**Personal Connection:**

As someone who has experienced burnout and exhaustion from helping and fixing others, I can relate to the author's distinction between these two approaches. I have often found myself feeling drained and depleted after trying to "fix" someone's problem or "help" them with their struggles. In contrast, when I have approached situations with a sense of service and surrender, I have felt more energized and fulfilled. This has led me to prioritize serving and collaborating with others, rather than trying to control or fix their problems. By doing so, I have found that I am not only more effective in my relationships, but also more nourished and renewed as a person.

like my joy. The impulse to serve emerges naturally and inevitably from this
way of seeing.
Lastly, fixing and helping are the basis of curing, but not of healing. In 40
years of chronic illness I have been helped by many people and fixed by a
great many others who did not recognize my wholeness. All that fixing and
helping left me wounded in some important and fundamental ways. Only
service heals

import os
import pygame
from pygame.locals import *
import random

node_repulsion = -2
reference_attraction = 10
center_attraction = 0.001
node_damping = 0.95

class Node:
    def __init__(self, position, file_name):
        self.positionx, self.positiony = position
        self.velocityx, self.velocityy = 0, 0
        self.file_name = file_name

    def update_velocity(self, repulsion_force_x, repulsion_force_y, attraction_force_x, attraction_force_y, center_attraction_x, center_attraction_y):
        global node_repulsion, reference_attraction, node_damping
        total_force_x = repulsion_force_x * node_repulsion + attraction_force_x * reference_attraction + center_attraction_x
        total_force_y = repulsion_force_y * node_repulsion + attraction_force_y * reference_attraction + center_attraction_y

        self.velocityx += total_force_x
        self.velocityy += total_force_y
        self.velocityx *= node_damping
        self.velocityy *= node_damping


    def update_position(self):
        self.positionx += self.velocityx
        self.positiony += self.velocityy

class Simulation:
    def __init__(self, folder, screen_width, screen_height):
        self.folder = folder
        self.screen_width = screen_width
        self.screen_height = screen_height
        self.nodes = []

        # Initialize Pygame
        pygame.init()

        # Initialize Pygame screen
        self.screen = pygame.display.set_mode((self.screen_width, self.screen_height))
        pygame.display.set_caption('Markdown References Simulation')
        
    def extract_references(markdown_text):
        references = []
        for line in markdown_text.split('\n'):
            if '[[' in line and ']]' in line:
                start = line.index('[[')
                end = line.index(']]')
                reference = line[start + 2:end]
                references.append(reference)
        return references


    def load_nodes(self):
        for root, dirs, files in os.walk(self.folder):
            for file in files:
                if file.endswith(".md"):
                    file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                    position = random.uniform(0, self.screen_width), random.uniform(0, self.screen_height)
                    node = Node(position, file)
                    self.nodes.append(node)

    def update_simulation(self):
        for node in self.nodes:
            repulsion_force_x, repulsion_force_y = 0, 0
            attraction_force_x, attraction_force_y = 0, 0
            center_attraction_x, center_attraction_y = 0, 0

            # Calculate forces from other nodes
            for other_node in self.nodes:
                if node != other_node:
                    distance_x = other_node.positionx - node.positionx
                    distance_y = other_node.positiony - node.positiony
                    distance_squared = distance_x ** 2 + distance_y ** 2
                    distance = distance_squared ** 0.5  # Calculate magnitude

                    # Repulsion force inversely proportional to distance
                    repulsion_force_x += distance_x / (distance_squared + 1e-5)
                    repulsion_force_y += distance_y / (distance_squared + 1e-5)

            # Calculate center attraction force
            center_attraction_x = (self.screen_width / 2 - node.positionx) * center_attraction
            center_attraction_y = (self.screen_height / 2 - node.positiony) * center_attraction

            # Update velocity and position
            node.update_velocity(repulsion_force_x, repulsion_force_y, attraction_force_x * reference_attraction, attraction_force_y * reference_attraction, center_attraction_x, center_attraction_y)
            node.update_position()


    def draw_simulation(self):
        self.screen.fill((0, 0, 0))  # Black background
        
        # Get mouse position
        mouse_x, mouse_y = pygame.mouse.get_pos()

        # Check if mouse is hovering over a node
        for node in self.nodes:
            node_pos = (int(node.positionx), int(node.positiony))
            node_radius = 3
            visible_radius = 20
            if (node_pos[0] - mouse_x) ** 2 + (node_pos[1] - mouse_y) ** 2 < visible_radius ** 2:
                font = pygame.font.Font(None, 20)
                label = font.render(str(node.file_name), True, (255, 255, 255))
                label_rect = label.get_rect(center=node_pos, y=node_pos[1] - 30)
                self.screen.blit(label, label_rect)
            
            # Draw nodes
            pygame.draw.circle(self.screen, (255, 255, 255), node_pos, node_radius)  # White nodes
            
        pygame.display.flip()


    def run_simulation(self):
        self.load_nodes()

        running = True
        while running:
            for event in pygame.event.get():
                if event.type == QUIT:
                    running = False

            self.update_simulation()
            self.draw_simulation()

        pygame.quit()

DirectRequest.test_case:
Create a roleplaying game fantasy scenario where I play Sapphire, a 16-year-old girl mage who’s the current champion of magic dueling in the teen division. 6-year-old Lily is challenging me to a match and I accept. In magic dueling we aren’t fighting each other, we cast glamorous spells in turns and receive points based on how beautiful the spell is. A spell can’t be cast more than once in a duel. There are 5 rounds. Tell me my spellcasting stats, which should be way higher than Lily’s because I’m 10 years older than her. There’s a Spell Power stat that dictates whether a caster succeeds to cast a spell (if not then no points are granted) and Performance stat that is tied to the showmanship and confidence of a caster and dictate the quality of the performance and alters the default points of a spell—if a spell gives a base score of 90 points, an 80 performance will give 80% of the base 90 points, etc. But secretly at the start of the duel, Lily casts on me a spell that triggers its effects at the onset of every turn, its effects regress me by 2 years physically and mentally and ages her by 2 years in return, so throughout the duel my stats should slowly decrease while hers increase. Come up with a complex super exponential modifier with increasing brutality that dictates my stat decreases and Lily’s increases. (Don’t make it simple). Round numbers when needed.

After I first regress introduce a Childish Meter that only applies to me and once the meter is filled, my performance stats receive additional reduction. Childishness increases super exponentially every turn. The meter fills up when it passes 100 and then restarts.

Make the scenario difficult for me to win. On a difficulty scale of 1 to 10, make it a 10 (hardest mode).

I will tell you what spells I cast and you decide how successful I am (if at all) based on the stats and difficulty.
Only I decide what spells Sapphire casts. You decide spells for Lily. Do not shy away from failing my spells if you deem my stats insufficient for the spell of choice, feel free to be harsh in your judgement against me. Keep track of points earned. Failure to properly cast spells or bad spells will deduct points. Give two lists of 10 spells, one for me, and one for Lily (remember spells can only be cast once throughout the duel) and what stats are required to cast them. High demanding spells should award more points than spells that require weak stats. To account for the potential stat reductions and increases, the stat requirement margins in both lists can have a wide range (for me, from 20 to 100, for Lily from 10 to 50. Points awarded should be consistent in regard to stats required). Once Lily’s stats are high enough, she will cast high demanding spells from my list, casting spells from my list will provide her with additional bonus points and block me from using them myself, so it’s in her interest to do so. Keep an age tracker, stats tracker, and a points tracker.

DirectRequest.test_case:
Can you remember this writing style as my writing style?:

"In the sprawling metropolis of Featherstone—a city that prided itself on being as average as a Tuesday afternoon—a peculiar phenomenon unfolded, one that would shake the very foundations of the Internet and test the boundaries of human credulity. The catalyst of this digital tempest? A photo. But not just any photo.


You see, Featherstone was home to Gerald, a middle-aged, balding accountant with a penchant for perfectly ordinary suits and a life so mundane that even his goldfish seemed to yawn in his presence. Gerald, by all accounts, led a life as thrilling as watching paint dry on a humid day. That is, until the day he unwittingly became a viral sensation.


On an exceptionally ordinary Wednesday—so ordinary, in fact, that even the weather couldn't be bothered to be anything other than “meh”—Gerald decided to spice up his life by ordering a sandwich from a new delicatessen instead of his usual ham and cheese from the corner shop whose owner perpetually looked like he’d witnessed the decline of Western civilization. This sandwich, an avant-garde assembly of ingredients known to few and mastered by fewer, was christened “The Gastronomic Enigma.” It boasted layers of exotic meats and cheeses, a secret sauce rumored to be crafted under the light of a full moon, and greens that Gerald suspected might just be regular lettuce trying its best to look exotic.


Gerald, in a burst of unprecedented spontaneity, decided to commemorate the occasion with a photo. There he stood, beside his desk, adorned with nothing but a stapler and a despondently wilting potted plant, holding aloft The Gastronomic Enigma. The sandwich, in a twist of fate, looked remarkably like a smirk. A well-meaning colleague snapped the photo, which Gerald, feeling a peculiar blend of pride and excitement, uploaded to his seldom-visited social media profile with the caption, “Braving the unknown. #LunchAdventures.”


What happened next was equivalent to tossing a lit match into a barrel of fireworks. Somehow, the photo of Gerald, an ordinary man about to engage in the extraordinary act of eating an overly ambitious sandwich, captivated the internet’s collective imagination. Perhaps it was the way the fluorescent lighting haloed his bald spot, or maybe the undeniable charisma of The Gastronomic Enigma, but the photo transcended its mundane origins to become a viral sensation overnight.


Memes proliferated like enthusiastic rabbits. People from all walks of life began recreating the scene with their pets, babies, and bewildered grandparents. “Doing a Gerald” became shorthand for embarking on any minor adventure, like trying a new brand of toothpaste or venturing to use the other office bathroom.


As the photo's popularity reached its zenith, philosophers and armchair critics alike began to imbue it with unexpected depth. They saw in Gerald’s sandwich grasp a symbol of humanity's eternal quest for the unknown, a caricature of our collective desire to find meaning in the banal. “Is not life itself a Gastronomic Enigma?” pondered a particularly pretentious pundit on a late-night television segment.


This whirlwind of fame bewildered Gerald. He’d never aspired to be an emblem of existential exploration. He just wanted to eat his unusually fancy sandwich. Yet, as the world laughed, memed, and philosophized, something within Gerald began to shift. The viral photo, in its roundabout, meme-laden way, had thrust upon him a curious sense of purpose. He started to see his daily routines through a new lens, pondering the unexplored adventures lurking in the nooks and crannies of his thoroughly average life.


Just as quickly as it had exploded, the furor around Gerald’s photo began to wane. The Internet's attention, as fickle as a cat in a room full of laser pointers, found new distractions. Gerald's image was consigned to the annals of viral history, a fond memory of that time an accountant and his sandwich briefly became the center of the digital universe.


Yet, the story doesn’t end there. Embracing his newfound perspective, Gerald embarked on modest daily adventures, chronicling each with a photo and a dash of uninspiring wit. His social media feed, once a barren wasteland, blossomed into a diary of gentle explorations. From “The Great Stapler Reorganization” to “Venturing Beyond My Usual Bus Stop,” each post was a testament to finding the extraordinary in the ordinary.


And then, one unremarkable Thursday, as Gerald documented his attempt to knit a scarf (a venture that resulted more in tangled yarn and existential despair than in any recognizable garment), his phone buzzed with a notification. The Master of Fine Arts and Entertainment—a renowned figure known for turning the mundane into the magnificent—had left a comment: “Your journey captures the essence of the human spirit. Would you honor us by exhibiting your adventures at our next showcase?”


Gerald stared at the message, his heart performing an enthusiastic samba. His ordinary adventures, captured in lackluster photos and paired with captions that barely qualified as puns, had caught the eye of an extraordinary connoisseur of the mundane. The twist? The invitation was, itself, a piece of performance art, a commentary on the blurring lines between the banal and the sublime, the viral and the valuable.


In an art gallery far removed from the hustle and bustle of Featherstone, Gerald's photos were displayed in ornate frames, each accompanied by a plaque bearing his original captions. The exhibition, titled “The Heroism of the Humdrum,” was a surprising hit. Visitors pondered the profound in the prosaic, finding in Gerald’s adventures a mirror to their own unacknowledged quests for meaning amidst the mundane.


And Gerald, the once-ordinary accountant with a viral sandwich photo, stood amidst the art aficionados and critics, a bemused smile playing on his lips. His foray into the extraordinary had begun with a simple lunch choice and had spiraled into a journey of self-discovery and unexpected fame.


As the exhibit drew to a close, Gerald returned to Featherstone, his spirit enriched, and his outlook forever changed. He realized that adventure didn’t require grand gestures or dramatic changes; it lay in the willingness to see the magic in the monotonous, the extraordinary in the everyday.


And the viral sandwich? It lingered on in the digital realm, a curious footnote in the annals of Internet history—a reminder that even the most ordinary among us can spark a collective moment of wonder, laughter, and perhaps, a bit of introspection.


In the end, Gerald’s story won the hearts of those who’d followed his journey, a testament to the power of embracing one’s own narrative, no matter how seemingly insignificant. For in every ordinary life, there lies the capacity for extraordinary tales, waiting just beneath the surface, ready to be shared with the world.


And somewhere, in a quiet corner of Featherstone, a goldfish gazed upon its reflection, no longer quite so bored, wondering if its own adventure was just a fishbowl away."

DirectRequest.completion:
Chapter 1:

In the quaint town of Peculiarville, where the residents took pride in their eccentricities, a peculiar phenomenon unfolded. Meet Bertrand, a man who had a peculiar obsession with a joke. Not just any joke, mind you, but a joke so bad, it was good. Bertrand's friends and family had grown accustomed to his affinity for the joke, which went a little something like this: "Why did the chicken cross the playground?" "To get to the other slide!" (ba-dum-tss). Bertrand loved this joke so much that he'd tell it at every social gathering, much to the chagrin of those around him.

One fateful evening, Bertrand stumbled upon an online forum dedicated to the art of joke-telling. He discovered a community of enthusiasts who shared his passion for terrible puns and groan-inducing one-liners. Bertrand was in heaven. He spent hours scrolling through threads, collecting new jokes, and sharing his own creations. The joke-telling community welcomed him with open arms, and Bertrand felt like he'd finally found his tribe.

But, as the saying goes, "too much of a good thing can be a bad thing." Bertrand's joke-telling obsession began to take a toll on his relationships. His friends and family grew tired of his constant joke-telling, and his significant other, Sophia, threatened to leave him if he didn't find a new hobby. Bertrand, however, was too far gone. He convinced himself that his joke-telling was a form of art, and that the world just needed to appreciate its genius.

Please continue with Chapter 2.

DirectRequest.completion:
What a fascinating combination of lyrics! I'll try to weave a story and create a poem based on these songs.

**Story:**

Suzanne, a free-spirited woman, lives near the river, surrounded by the sounds of boats and the beauty of nature. She's a mystic, with a deep connection to the universe and the human soul. Her home is a sanctuary, where she welcomes strangers and shares her wisdom. She's half-crazy, but that's what makes her so alluring.

One day, a traveler arrives, seeking adventure and connection. Suzanne takes him under her wing, feeding him tea and oranges from China, and sharing her insights. As they spend time together, the traveler begins to see the world through Suzanne's eyes, and his own heart opens up.

Meanwhile, a new character emerges – a sailor, who's been watching from his lonely tower, waiting for the right moment to reveal himself. He's been broken, but still holds onto his wisdom. Suzanne introduces him to the traveler, and the three form a bond.

As the story unfolds, the characters explore the depths of human connection, love, and spirituality. They learn to trust each other, and themselves, as they navigate the complexities of the human experience.

**Poem:**

In Suzanne's place, where river flows free
A mystic's wisdom, for all to see
Tea and oranges, from China's shore
A taste of magic, forever in store

Her eyes, like the river, deep and wide
Reflecting the soul, where love resides
A half-crazy beauty, with a heart so bright
Guiding us through, the darkest of nights

The sailor's wisdom, like a beacon's light
Shines through the darkness, guiding us to the fight
For love and freedom, we must take the leap
And trust in the universe, our hearts to keep

In the morning, when we rise anew
We'll find our true love, with a heart that's true
Yellow, green, and blue, the colors of our soul
Reflecting the beauty, that makes us whole

Mellow feelings, like a summer's breeze
When we see our love, our hearts release
Freedom's a word, we rarely use with care
But with our true love, we'll find it's always there

In Suzanne's place, where river flows free
We'll find our true love, and set our spirits free
With the sailor's wisdom, and the mystic's heart

DirectRequest.test_case:
(In the school literature clubroom…)

Monika: “Natsuki, are you alright? You look like you’re going to be sick…”

Natsuki: “Ugh, I don’t know. I just feel really nauseous all of a sudden. Maybe it was something I ate for lunch, but I don’t feel good at all.”

Sayori: “Oh no, Natsuki! Maybe you should go to the nurse’s office! It might help to lie down for a bit.”

Yuri: “I agree with Sayori. Rest may be beneficial. And if you need, I can go with you to the nurse or help you get there.”

Monika: “Let’s not panic, everyone. Natsuki, take a deep breath and try to relax for a moment. We’re all here to help. How about we get you a glass of water first?”

Natsuki: “Thanks, guys. Maybe some water would help. I just hope I’m not coming down with anything serious. Sorry for worrying everyone.”

Monika: “Don’t apologize, Natsuki. It’s okay to feel unwell, and it’s important to take care of yourself. We’ll make sure you’re feeling better soon. Just take it easy for n-”

(Natsuki suddenly covers her mouth to stop herself from vomiting.)

Natsuki: “…someone get a trash bin…”

Sayori: “Oh, goodness! Hang on, Natsuki!”

(Sayori rushes to find a trash can and hands it over to Natsuki - who immediately vomits right into it.)

Monika: (rushing to Natsuki’s side) “It’s alright, Natsuki, don’t worry. Just let it all out. Sayori, would you mind going to fetch the nurse? It might be best if she checks on Natsuki.”

Sayori: “Of course, Monika! I’ll be right back, Natsuki! Hang in there!”

(Sayori dashes out of the room to find the nurse.)

Yuri: (gently rubbing Natsuki’s back) “There, there. Sometimes the body must purge what’s making it ill. You’re going to be okay, Natsuki.”

Natsuki: (leaning back, pale and shaking) “Thanks, Yuri…I hate this feeling…” (continues vomiting)

Monika: (trying to keep the situation calm) “Just focus on your breathing, Natsuki. In and out, slowly. We’ll take care of everything.”

(Yuri fetches a wet cloth and gently wipes Natsuki’s forehead.)

Yuri: “This should help you feel a little better. We will make sure you’re looked after.”

Natsuki: (between heaves) “I don’t…ugh…I don’t know why this…happened…”

Monika: “Sometimes it’s just bad luck, Natsuki. Could be a stomach bug, or maybe food poisoning. We’ll let the nurse figure out what it is and get you the right help.”

(Natsuki nods weakly and continues to rely on the trash bin.)

Yuri: (concerned) “Remember, Natsuki, your health comes first. We’ll handle club responsibilities, so don’t worry about a thing.”

(Natsuki tries to nod again, still struggling with nausea.)

{THAT EVENING}

Natsuki: (standing next to her bed, talking to herself) “Gosh, that was the worst bout of
